title: PredictaBoard: Benchmarking LLM Score Predictability
author: Lorenzo Pacchiardi (Leverhulme Centre for the Future of Intelligence, University of Cambridge), Konstantinos Voudouris (Institute for Human-Centered AI, Helmholtz Zentrum Munich), Ben Slater (Leverhulme Centre for the Future of Intelligence, University of Cambridge), Fernando Martínez-Plumed (VRAIN, Universitat Politècnica de València), José Hernández-Orallo (VRAIN, Universitat Politècnica de València), Lexin Zhou (VRAIN, Universitat Politècnica de València), Wout Schellaert (VRAIN, Universitat Politècnica de València), ..., José Hernández-Orallo (VRAIN, Universitat Politècnica de València)
relevance_why: The methods discussed on LLM predictability can provide insights into how predictable audio models can be developed, enhancing the robustness of audio generation tasks.
background: The paper introduces a benchmarking framework to assess the reliability of score predictors in anticipating when Large Language Models (LLMs) will produce accurate outputs.
contribution: PredictaBoard introduces a benchmarking framework for assessing the predictability of LLMs, achieving a robust evaluation of model reliability across diverse tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous approaches focused on aggregate performance metrics without providing robust predictability assessments at the instance level.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by emphasizing the predictability of LLMs through the use of combined metrics that evaluate both model performance and the accuracy of score predictors.

key_innovation: Establishes the Accuracy-Rejection Curve as a meaningful way to visualize and compute the performance predictability of LLMs.
real_world_impact: This framework aims to foster the development of safer AI systems by improving predictability, which is crucial in high-stakes environments like autonomous vehicles or healthcare.
limitations: Only external anticipative assessors are considered, which may restrict the scope of explored methodologies.

new_terms.Accuracy-Rejection Curve: **Accuracy-Rejection Curve** is a graphical representation that shows the accuracy of a model as instances are rejected based on predicted confidence thresholds.
new_terms.predictably valid region: **Predictably valid region** refers to the area within which the operational reliability of a model can be anticipated based on specific thresholds of error tolerance.

open_sourcing: Code for the benchmark can be found at https://github.com/Kinds-of-Intelligence-CFI/PredictaBoard
